member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Bilinear
member.summary: A class for bilinear interpolation.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Description: This method interpolates functions of two variables using repeated linear interpolation. First linear interpolation is performed in one direction, and then again in another.
Methods are designed to be compatible with the VBA Macro 'Interpolate Version 2.0.0' November 2017, USACE Risk Management Center

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.CubicSpline
member.summary: A class for cubic spline interpolation.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: Spline interpolation uses a piecewise polynomial called a spline as the interpolant. Instead of fitting a single, high degree polynomial to all of the given values at once, spline interpolation fits low-degree polynomials to small subsets of values. For cubic spline interpolation, polynomials of degree 3 are used.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Search
member.summary: A class for searching a list.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This class has 3 search methods: Sequential, Bisection, and Hunt.
Sequential search, or linear search, checks each element in a list until a match is found or the whole list has been searched.
The bisection method, also known as binary search, starts off by comparing the target value (i.e. value being searched for in the array) against the middle element of the list. If the target value and middle element are not equal, the half of the list in which the target cannot lie is eliminated. If the list sorted in ascending order, if the target is less than the middle element, the second half of the list of values greater than the middle element is eliminated. If the target is greater than the middle element then the first half of the list is eliminated. Then, the algorithm starts again, comparing the middle element of the new, smaller list against the target element. This continues until the target value is found or until the remaining half being empty.

member.remarks: Given an array of X and given a value of X, returns a location J such that X is between XArray(J) and XArray(J+1). The XArray must be monotonic, either increasing or decreasing. J = 0 or J = XArray.Length is returned to indicate that X is out of range. The SearchStart is taken as the initial guess for J on output.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.LineSimplification
member.summary: Class to perform line simplification using the RDP algorithm.
member.remarks:
Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Description: The Ramer-Douglas-Peucker algorithm decimates a curve composed of line segments to a similar curve with fewer points. The purpose is, given a curve composed of line segments,, to find a similar curve with fewer points. "Dissimilar" in this case is defined based on the maximum distance between the original curve and the simplified curve (in this class, that maximum distance is user defined). The simplified curve consists of a subset of the points that defined the original curve.
References:

member.summary: Implements the Ramer-Douglas-Peucker algorithm
member.param: The list of input ordinates that make up the original curve
The max allowable distance between the original curve and outputted simplified curve
The ordinates that make up simplified curve produced by the algorithm

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Statistics.GoodnessOfFit
member.summary: A class containing goodness-of-fit measures.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.GoodnessOfFit.AIC(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) used for model selection among a finite set of models; the model with the lowest AIC is preferred. When comparing multiple model fits, additional model parameters often yield larger, optimized log-likelihood values. Unlike the optimized log-likelihood value, AIC penalizes for more complex models, i.e., models with additional parameters.
member.returns: The AIC value for the model

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.GoodnessOfFit.AICc(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), corrected for small sample sizes, used for model selection among a finite set of models; the model with the lowest AIC is preferred. When comparing multiple model fits, additional model parameters often yield larger, optimized log-likelihood values. Unlike the optimized log-likelihood value, AIC penalizes for more complex models, i.e., models with additional parameters.
member.returns: The AIC value for the model

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.GoodnessOfFit.BIC(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) used for model selection among a finite set of models; the model with the lowest BIC is preferred. Like AIC, BIC uses the optimal log-likelihood function value and penalizes for more complex models, i.e., models with additional parameters. The penalty of BIC is a function of the sample size, and so is typically more severe than that of AIC.
member.returns: The BIC value for the model

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.GoodnessOfFit.AICWeights(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns an array of weights based on a list of model AIC values.
member.param: The list of model AIC values.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.GoodnessOfFit.BICWeights(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Returns an array of weights based on a list of model BIC values.
member.param: The list of model BIC values.

member.param: The list of observed values to measure against.
The list of modeled values to compare against the observed values.
member.returns: The RMSE of the model

Generalized Grubbs-Beck Test.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics
member.summary: Contains functions for computing running statistics of a sample of data.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
References: This class is copied from the Math.NET Numerics library,

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an empty running statistics class.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Constructs running statistics based on a list of values.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Count
member.summary: Gets the total number of samples.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Minimum
member.summary: Returns the minimum value in the sample data. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Maximum
member.summary: Returns the maximum value in the sample data. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Mean
member.summary: Returns the sample mean, an estimate of the population mean. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Variance
member.summary: Returns the sample variance. On a dataset of size N, it will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationVariance
member.summary: Returns the population variance. On a dataset of size N, it will use an N normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.StandardDeviation
member.summary: Returns the sample standard deviation. On a dataset of size N, it will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationStandardDeviation
member.summary: Returns the population standard deviation. On a dataset of size N, it will use an N normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.CoefficientOfVariation
member.summary: Returns the coefficient of variation of the sample.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Skewness
member.summary: Returns the sample skewness. Uses a normalizer (Bessel's correction; type 2). Returns NaN if data has less than three entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationSkewness
member.summary: Returns the population skewness. Does not use a normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset (type 1). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Kurtosis
member.summary: Returns the sample kurtosis. Uses a normalizer (Bessel's correction; type 2). Returns NaN if data has less than four entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationKurtosis
member.summary: Returns the population kurtosis. Does not use a normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset (type 1). Returns NaN if data has less than three entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Push(System.Double)
member.summary: Updates the running statistics by adding another data value (in-place).

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Push(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Updates the running statistics by adding a sequence of data values (in-place).

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Combine(Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics,Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics)
member.summary: Create a new running statistics over the combined samples of two existing running statistics.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics.op_Addition(Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics,Numerics.Data.Statistics.RunningStatistics)
member.summary: Create a new running statistics over the combined samples of two existing running statistics.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests
member.summary: A class for performing statistical hypothesis tests.
member.remarks:
Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Description: This is a method of statistical inference used to decide whether the data sufficiently support a particular hypothesis, typically through the calculation of some test statistic. The null hypothesis (H0) is assumed to be true until proven otherwise through the tests. In this class the p value is calculated to determine whether or not to reject the null hypothesis. If the p value is less than the specified significance level, the null hypothesis is rejected in favor of the alternative hypothesis (Ha).
References:

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.OneSampleTtest(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: The one sample t-Test compares the mean of the sample to a hypothesized population mean. One rejects H0 if the p-value of the statistic is less than the significance level.
member.returns: Returns the 2-sided p-value of the test statistic.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.EqualVarianceTtest(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: The t-test determines if there is a significant difference between the means of two samples drawn from populations with equal variances. One rejects H0 if the p-value of the statistic is less than the significance level.
member.returns: Returns the 2-sided p-value of the test statistic.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.UnequalVarianceTtest(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: The t-test determines if there is a significant difference between the means of two samples drawn from populations with unequal variances. One rejects H0 if the p-value of the statistic is less than the significance level.
member.returns: Returns the 2-sided p-value of the test statistic.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.PairedTtest(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: The paired t-test determines whether the mean difference between two sets of observations is zero. One rejects H0 if the p-value of the statistic is less than the significance level.
member.returns: Returns the 2-sided p-value of the test statistic.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.Ftest(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: The F-test for significantly different variances. One rejects H0 if the p-value of the statistic is less than the significance level.
member.returns: Returns the p-value of the test statistic.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.FtestModels(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: The F-test comparing two models. The null, H0, states that the restricted and full models are equal. One rejects the null if the p-value of the statistic is less than the significance level.
member.param: The sum of squared errors (SSE) of the restricted model.
The sum of squared errors (SSE) of the full model.
The degrees of freedom of the restricted model.
The degrees of freedom of the full model.
The p-value of the test statistic.

member.name: M:Numerics.Data.Statistics.HypothesisTests.JarqueBeraTest(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: The Jarque-Bera test for normality. One rejects H0 of normality if the p-value of the JB statistic is less than the significance level.
member.returns: Returns the p-value of the test statistic.
member.remarks: The Jarque-Bera normality test statistics is a chi-squared random variable with 2 degrees of freedom.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Statistics.Autocorrelation
member.summary: Computes the autocovariance, autocorrelation, or partial autocorrelation function.
member.remarks:
Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Description: Autocovariance is a function that gives the covariance (measure of the joint variability of two random variables) of the process with itself at pairs of time points. Autocorrelation is the similarity of between observations of a random variable as a function of the time lag between them. The partial autocorrelation function gives the partial correlation of a stationary time series with it own lagged values of the time series at all short lags. This is in contrast with the autocorrelation function that does not control for other lags.
References:

member.summary: Computes the autocovariance, autocorrelation, or partial autocorrelation function.
member.param: The list of data to evaluate.

The maximum lag at which to estimate the function. Default is 10*log10(N/m) where N is the number of observations. Will be automatically limited to one less than the number of observations in the series.
The type of function to be computed. Default is correlation.
member.returns: A n x 2 matrix, with being the number of given input data points. The first column contains the lag and the second column contains the function evaluated at the given values.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Statistics.PlottingPositions
member.summary: Contains plotting position formulas.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: The choice of quantiles from a theoretical distribution can depend upon context and purpose. Several different formulas have been used or proposed as affine symmetrical plotting positions. Such formulas have the form (k a) / (n + 1 2a) for some value of a in the range from 0 to 1, which gives a range between k / (n + 1) and (k 1) / (n - 1).

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.Statistics.Correlation
member.summary: Contains methods for determining the correlation of two data sets.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This class contains a shared functions for Pearson and Spearman Correlation Coefficients. The Pearson correlation coefficient measures linear correlation between two sets of data. The Spearman correlation coefficient is a nonparametric measure of rank correlation (i.e. measures the strength and direction of association between two ranked variables).

list.item: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.OrderedPairedData
member.summary: Class designed to store x-y data that is ordered for both the x and y values.
member.remarks:
Authors: Woodrow Fields, USACE Risk Management Center, woodrow.l.fields@usace.army.mil
Description: The most common use case for this class is to store curve data such as a cumulative distribution function. One of the more powerful functions associated with this class is the Transform() function which allows to transform the OrderedPairedData class with another to create a new class. Common use cases of the Transform() function include transforming a flood frequency function into a stage frequency function using a flow-stage rating curve.

member.name: T:Numerics.Data.LinearRegression
member.summary: A class for performing linear regression.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: Linear regression works to estimate the linear relationship between a single, scalar response (dependent) variable and one or more explanatory (independent) variables. This implementation estimates Y = + X + e, where e ~ N(0,), and fits the linear regression model using singular value decomposition (SVD).

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.Copulas.ArchimedeanCopula
member.summary: Declares common functionality of all Archimedean Copulas.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.Copulas.ArchimedeanCopula.InverseCDF(System.Double,System.Double)
member.remarks: This method is based on Genest et al. 1986 1) Two independent uniformly distributed U(0,1) random variates, u and v, are generated. 2) Two new variables, s and w, are obtained as s = GeneratorPrime(u) / v and w = GeneratorPrimeInverse(s). 3) Another variable v is obtained as v = GeneratorInverse(Generator(w) - Generator(u)) 4) The pairs u and v are the simulated pair, preserving the dependence structure. 5) Both these u and v in the range [0,1]. These simulated pairs of u and v are then back-transformed through their corresponding marginal distributions.

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.Copulas.CopulaEstimationMethod
member.summary: Copula Estimation Methods.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

member.name: F:Numerics.Distributions.Copulas.CopulaEstimationMethod.FullLikelihood
member.summary: The full maximum likelihood estimation method requires parametric marginal distributions to predict the data. The marginal distributions and the copula dependency are estimated simultaneously.

member.name: F:Numerics.Distributions.Copulas.CopulaEstimationMethod.PseudoLikelihood
member.summary: A semi-parametric approach that uses the plotting positions of the data to estimate the copula dependency using maximum likelihood.

member.name: F:Numerics.Distributions.Copulas.CopulaEstimationMethod.InferenceFromMargins
member.summary: The inference from margins (IFM) method includes two procedures: 1) marginal distributions are independently estimated from the observed values; 2) the copula dependency is estimate through the maximization of the likelihood function given the marginal distributions.

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.PertPercentile
member.summary: The Pert percentile distribution.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

In probability and statistics, the PERT distribution is a family of continuous probability distributions defined by the minimum (a), most likely (b) and maximum (c) values that a variable can take. It is a transformation of the four-parameter Beta distribution.
This version of the PERT is parameterized using the 5th, 50th, and 95th percentiles.

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.BivariateCDF(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: A function for computing the bivariate normal CDF.

remarks.para: This code was copied from Accord Math Library, http://accord-framework.net

This method is based on the work done by Alan Genz, Department of Mathematics, Washington State University. Pullman, WA 99164-3113 Email: alangenz@wsu.edu. This work was shared under a 3-clause BSD license. Please see source file for more details and the actual license text.

This function is based on the method described by Drezner, Z and G.O. Wesolowsky, (1989), On the computation of the bivariate normal integral, Journal of Statist. Comput. Simul. 35, pp. 101-107, with major modifications for double precision, and for |R| close to 1.

member.param: The z variate for the first Normal.
The z variate for the second Normal.

member.name: F:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.X
member.summary: Gauss Legendre Points and Weights, N = 6, 12, and 20

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.MVNDST(System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: A subroutine for computing multivariate normal probabilities. This subroutine uses an algorithm given in the paper "Numerical Computation of Multivariate Normal Probabilities", in J.of Computational and Graphical Stat., 1(1992), pp. 141-149, by Alan Genz Department of Mathematics Washington State University Pullman, WA 99164-3113 Email : AlanGenz @wsu.edu
member.param: array of correlation coefficients; the correlation coefficient in row I column J of the correlation matrix should be stored in CORREL(J + ((I-2)*(I-1))/2 ), for J less than I. The correlation matrix must be positive semidefinite.
maximum number of function values allowed. This parameter can be used to limit the time.A sensible strategy is to start with MAXPTS = 1000 * N, and then increase MAXPTS if ERROR is too large.
estimated absolute error, with 99% confidence level.

termination status parameter: if INFORM = 0, normal completion with ERROR < EPS; if INFORM = 1, completion with ERROR > EPS and MAXPTS function values used; increase MAXPTS to decrease ERROR; if INFORM = 2, N > 500 or N less than 1.

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.MVNDFN(System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: Integrand subroutine.

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.COVSRT(System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32[],System.Double[],System.Int32@,System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Subroutine to sort integration limits and determine Cholesky factor.

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.DKBVRC(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Func{System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Double},System.Double,System.Double,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
Automatic Multidimensional Integration Subroutine AUTHOR: Alan Genz Department of Mathematics Washington State University Pulman, WA 99164-3113 Email: AlanGenz @wsu.edu
Last Change: 7/3/7
DKBVRC computes an approximation to the integral
1 1 1 I I ... I F(X) dx(NDIM)...dx(2)dx(1) 0 0 0
DKBVRC uses randomized Korobov rules for the first 100 variables. The primary references are "Randomization of Number Theoretic Methods for Multiple Integration" R.Cranley and T.N.L.Patterson, SIAM J Numer Anal, 13, pp. 904-14, and "Optimal Parameters for Multidimensional Integration", P.Keast, SIAM J Numer Anal, 10, pp.831-838. If there are more than 100 variables, the remaining variables are integrated using the rules described in the reference "On a Number-Theoretical Integration Method" H.Niederreiter, Aequationes Mathematicae, 8(1972), pp. 304-11.
member.param: Number of variables, must exceed 1, but not exceed 40.

minimum number of function evaluations allowed. MINVLS must not exceed MAXVLS.If MINVLS < 0 then the routine assumes a previous call has been made with the same integrand and continues that calculation.
maximum number of function evaluations allowed.
EXTERNALly declared user defined function to be integrated. It must have parameters (NDIM, Z), where Z is a real array of dimension NDIM.

INFORM = 0 for normal exit, when ABSERR <= MAX(ABSEPS, RELEPS* ABS(FINEST)) and INTVLS <= MAXCLS. INFORM = 1 If MAXVLS was too small to obtain the required accuracy.In this case a value FINEST is returned with estimated absolute accuracy ABSERR.

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.BVNMVN(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32[],System.Double)
member.summary: A function for computing bivariate normal probabilities.
member.param: array of integration limits flags: if INFIN(I) = 0, Ith limits are(-infinity, UPPER(I)]; if INFIN(I) = 1, Ith limits are[LOWER(I), infinity); if INFIN(I) = 2, Ith limits are[LOWER(I), UPPER(I)].

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.MultivariateNormal.PHINVS(System.Double)
member.summary:
ALGORITHM AS241 APPL.STATIST. (1988) VOL. 37, NO. 3
Produces the normal deviate Z corresponding to a given lower tail area of p.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.KappaFour
member.summary: The Kappa-4 distribution.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

item.description: If h = -1 , then the Kappa-4 is the Generalized Logistic distribution.
If h = 0 , then the Kappa-4 is the Generalized Extreme Value distribution.
If h = 1 , then the Kappa-4 is the Generalized Pareto distribution.

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.PertPercentileZ
member.summary: The Pert percentile z distribution.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

In probability and statistics, the PERT distribution is a family of continuous probability distributions defined by the minimum (a), most likely (b) and maximum (c) values that a variable can take. It is a transformation of the four-parameter Beta distribution.
This version of the PERT is parameterized using the 5th, 50th, and 95th percentiles in Normal Z space.

member.name: M:Numerics.Distributions.PertPercentileZ.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a PERT distribution with 5th = 0.05 (z = -1.64), 50th = 0.5 (z = 0.0), and 95th = 0.95 (z = 1.64).

member.summary: Constructs a PERT distribution with specified 5th, 50th, and 95th percentiles.
member.param: The 5th percentile value of the distribution, in Z-space.

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.ChiSquared
member.summary: The Chi-Squared () probability distribution.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

In probability theory and statistics, the chi-square distribution (also chi-squared or -distribution) with k degrees of freedom Is the distribution of a sum of the squares of k independent standard normal random variables. It Is one of the most widely used probability distributions in inferential statistics, e.g. in hypothesis testing, or in construction of confidence intervals.

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.Pert
member.summary: The PERT probability distribution.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

In probability and statistics, the PERT distribution is a family of continuous probability distributions defined by the minimum (a), most likely (b) and maximum (c) values that a variable can take. It is a transformation of the four-parameter Beta distribution.

member.name: T:Numerics.Distributions.GammaDistribution
member.summary: Gamma distribution.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
The gamma distribution is a two-parameter family of continuous probability distributions. There are three different parameterizations in common use:

item.description: With a shape parameter k and a scale parameter .
With a shape parameter = k and an inverse scale parameter = 1/, called a rate parameter.
With a shape parameter k and a mean parameter = k/.

remarks.para: In each of these three forms, both parameters are positive real numbers. The parameterization with k and appears to be more common in econometrics and certain other applied fields, where e.g. the gamma distribution is frequently used to model waiting times. For instance, in life testing, the waiting time until death is a random variable that is frequently modeled with a gamma distribution. This is the default construction method for this class.
This class only uses the parameterization described in the first bullet.

If k is an integer, then the distribution represents an Erlang distribution; i.e., the sum of k independent exponentially distributed random variables, each of which has a mean of (which is equivalent to a rate parameter of 1/).

The gamma distribution is the maximum entropy probability distribution for a random variable X for which E[X] = k = / is fixed and greater than zero, and E[ln(X)] = (k) + ln() = () ln() is fixed ( is the digamma function).

References: This code was developed using two primary sources: 1) Wikipedia; and 2) the Accord Math Library.
Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Gamma distribution. Available on:
Accord Math Library,

member.name: T:Numerics.MachineLearning.KNearestNeighbors
member.summary: The k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) algorithm.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

k-NN is a simple method for applying supervised learning. When training a k-NN model, the model practically memorizes all locations of all the points and their values. When it is time to use the model for predictions, the model takes the input data and calculates the k-nearest points to that input.

member.name: T:Numerics.MachineLearning.NaiveBayes
member.summary: A class for Gaussian Naive Bayes Classification.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para: The Naive Bayes classifier is a "probabilistic classifier" based on applying Bayes' theorem with strong (naive) independence assumption between features.
The class implements Gaussian Naive Bayes, which assumes the features associated with each class are continuous and distributed according to a Normal (Gaussian) distribution.

member.name: T:Numerics.MachineLearning.GaussianMixtureModel
member.summary: Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) for classification.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

A Gaussian mixture model is a probabilistic model that assumes all the data points are generated from a mixture of a finite number of Gaussian distributions with unknown parameters. One can think of mixture models as generalizing k-means clustering to incorporate information about the covariance structure of the data as well as the centers of the latent Gaussian distributions.

member.name: T:Numerics.MachineLearning.KMeans
member.summary: k-Means clustering.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

k-Means clustering is a method of vector quantization, originally from signal processing, that aims to partition n observations into k clusters in which each observation belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean (cluster centers or cluster centroid), serving as a prototype of the cluster.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Integration.Miser
member.summary: A class for Miser, the recursive stratified sampling algorithm for multidimensional integration.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: The Miser method aims to reduce overall error by concentrating integration points in the regions of highest variance. The smallest error estimate is obtained by allocating sample points in proportion to the standard deviation of the function in each sub-region. This algorithm bisects the integration region along one coordinate axis at each step. The direction is chose by examining all possible bisections and selecting whichever will minimize the combined variance. This procedure is repeated recursively for each of the two half spaces down to a user-specified depth where each sub-region is integrated using a plain Monte Carlo estimate.

item.description: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.
"Numerical Recipes: The art of Scientific Computing, Third Edition. Press et al. 2017.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Integration.SimpsonsRule
member.summary: A class for Simpson's rule integration. Integration steps are refined until convergence.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: Simpson's rule approximates the integral by splitting the interval and evaluating the function at those split points. The most basic implementation of this is the following equation for the integral of f(x) over [a, b] with 2 subdivisions:
b f(x) dx ~ S(a, b) = (b - a) / 6 * [ f(a) + 4*f(m) + f(b) ] a
where m is the midpoint [ (a+b) / 2 ] between a and b. The more subdivisions there are, i.e. the more refined the steps are, the more accurate the approximation becomes.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Integration.AdaptiveSimpsonsRule
member.summary: A class that performs adaptive Simpson's integration.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: Adaptive Simpson's rule uses an estimate of the error that comes from calculating a definite integral with Simpson's rule. If the error between the previous evaluation of the rule and the current evaluation of the rule exceeds a certain specified tolerance, the rule calls for subdividing the interval. Adaptive Simpson's rule is applied to each subinterval in a recursive manner until the error qualifications are met.
| S(a, b) - S(a, m) + S(m, b) | < epsilon
where a and b are the bounds of integration and m is the midpoint between them.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Integration.TrapezoidalRule
member.summary: A class for Trapezoidal rule integration. Integration steps are refined until convergence.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: In its most basic form, the Trapezoidal rule approximates the region under the graph of f(x) as a trapezoid and calculating its area as:
b f(x) dx ~ T(a, b) = (b - a) * [ f(a) + f(b) ] / 2 a
This method can also be seen as averaging the left and right Riemann sums. Moreover, the interval can be subdivided to improve the accuracy of the approximation, with the trapezoidal rule applied to every sub-interval. Here the integration steps are refined, i.e. the interval is subdivided, until convergence.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Integration.Vegas
member.summary: A class for adaptive Monte Carlo integration for multidimensional integration.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This method aims to reduce error in Monte Carlo simulations by using a probability distribution function to concentrate the search in those areas of the integrand that make the greatest contribution.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.AugmentedLagrange
member.summary: The Augmented Lagrange constrained optimization method.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This method replaces the constrained optimization problem with a series of unconstrained problems and adds a penalty term to the objective, while also adding a third term designed to mimic a Lagrange multiplier. In other words, the unconstrained objective is the Lagrangian of the constrained problem, with an additional penalty term.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.MLSL
member.summary: The Multi-Level Single Linkage (MLSL) optimization method.
member.remarks:
Authors:
Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Brian Skahill, USACE Engineer Research and Development Center Coastal and Hydraulics Laboratory, brian.e.skahill@usace.army.mil
Description:
The key optimization steps are as follows:
Generate sample points and function values. Add N points, drawn from a uniform distribution over S, to the (initially empty) set of sample points, and evaluate f(x) at each new sample point.
Reduce the sample points. Sort the entire sample of kN points in order of increasing object function values. Select the kN points with the lowest objective function values. This resultant set, Rk, is called the reduced sample.
Select start points for local searches. Determine a (possibly empty) subset of the sample points from which to start local searches.
Decide whether to stop. If stopping rule is satisfied, regard the lowest local minimizer as the global minimizer, otherwise go to step 1.
References:
Implements routine described by Kan A.H.G.R., Boender C.G.E., Timmer G.T. (1985) A Stochastic Approach to Global Optimization. In: Schittkowski K. (eds) Computational Mathematical Programming. NATO ASI Series (Series F: Computer and Systems Sciences), vol 15. Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.MultiStart
member.summary: The Multi-Start (MS) optimization method.

remarks.para: Authors: Brian Skahill, USACE Engineer Research and Development Center Coastal and Hydraulics Laboratory, brian.e.skahill@usace.army.mil

Description: With the Multi-Start (MS) approach, a local search procedure P is applied to each point in the random sample; the best local minimum found in this way is our candidate for the global minimum
Draw a point from the uniform distribution over S.
Apply P to the new sample point.
The local minimum x* identified with the lowest function value is the candidate value for x^,. Return to Step 1, unless a stopping criterion is satisfied.

While optimal Bayesian stopping rules can be specified for Multi-Start, the only stopping criterion implemented for this simple ("folklore") global optimization method is the maximum number of local searches to perform.

Implements routine described by Kan A.H.G.R., Boender C.G.E., Timmer G.T. (1985) A Stochastic Approach to Global Optimization. In: Schittkowski K. (eds) Computational Mathematical Programming. NATO ASI Series (Series F: Computer and Systems Sciences), vol 15. Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.ParticleSwarm
member.summary: The Particle Swarm optimization algorithm.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This method optimizes a problem by iteratively trying to improve a candidate solution with a given measure of quality. Using a population of candidate solutions, called particles, these particles move around in the search space. Each particles's movement is influenced by its local best known position. These positions are updated as better positions are found by other particles, and the swarm is expected to move toward the best solutions.

item.description: Implements routine described by Kockenderfer and Wheeler. "Algorithms for Optimization" (2019).

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.SimulatedAnnealing
member.summary: The adaptive simulated annealing algorithm.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This algorithm is interpreted as a slow decrease in the probability of accepting worse solutions as the solution space is explored. Accepting the worse solutions allows for a more extensive search for the global solution. At each step, the algorithm randomly selects a solution close to the current one, measures its quality, and probabilistically decides moving between the two states.

item.description: Implements routine described by Corana et al. "Minimizing Multimodal Functions of Continuous Variables with 'Simulated Annealing' Algorithm" (1987).

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.ADAM
member.summary: The Adaptive Movement (Adam) optimization algorithm. The objective function must be differentiable and convex.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: Adaptive Movement Estimation algorithm, or Adam for short, is an extension to the gradient descent optimization algorithm. Adam is designed to accelerate the optimization process, e.g. decrease the number of function evaluations required to reach the optima, or to improve the capability of the optimization algorithm, e.g. result in a better final result.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.BFGS
member.summary: Contains the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (BFGS) optimization algorithm.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This is an iterative method for solving unconstrained nonlinear optimization problems. It gradually improves an approximation to the Hessian matrix of the loss function, obtained from gradient evaluations via a generalized secant method.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.DifferentialEvolution
member.summary: The Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm, which finds a global minima when no gradient is available.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This method optimizes a problem by trying to improve a candidate solution with regard to a given measure of quality. DE maintains a population of candidate solutions, creating new ones by combining existing ones, and keeping whichever solution has the best score or fitness on the optimization problem. Because the problem is treated as merely a measure of quality for the candidate solution, the gradient is not needed, and the problem does not need to be differentiable.

item.description: Implements routine described by Price et al. "Differential Evolution: A Practical Approach to Global Optimization" (1998).

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.Powell
member.summary: Contains the Powell optimization algorithm. The function need not be differentiable, and no derivatives are taken.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This method minimizes the function by bi-directionally searching along search vectors via Brent's method. The minima of these search vectors are recorded and used to create new search vectors, as the current ones are deleted after use. The algorithm iterates until no significant improvement is made.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.BrentSearch
member.summary: The Brent optimization algorithm. The function need not be differentiable, and no derivatives are taken.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This class contains methods for finding the minimum or maximum of a function using Brent's method. Brent's method is a hybrid root-finding algorithm that combines the bisection method, secant method, and inverse quadratic interpolation.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.GoldenSection
member.summary: The Golden-Section optimization algorithm. The function need not be differentiable, and no derivatives are taken.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This class contains methods for finding the minimum or maximum of a function using the Golden-Section method. This method operates by successively narrowing the range of values on the specified interval. When searching for a minimum, the central point is always less than or equal to the outer points, assuring that a minimum is contained between the outer points.

item.description: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.ShuffledComplexEvolution
member.summary: The Shuffled Complex Evolution (SCE-UA) algorithm, which finds a global minima when no gradient is available.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: The main steps of the algorithm are as follows
Randomly initialize s sample points in the feasible region, and calculate their objective function values.
Rank the sample points in ascending order by objective function values.
Divide the s sorted points into p complexes, and each complex contains m points.
Evolve each complex times with the competitive complex evolution (CCE) algorithm. In each evolution, q points in a complex are selected to form a subcomplex, and the subcomplex is adjusted times using reflection, contraction, and mutation steps.
Mix all points in the evolved complexes and sort them in ascending order of objective function value.
Determine whether the termination criteria are met, if not, return to Step 3.

item.description: Implements Duan et al. (1992) SCE-UA probabilistic search algorithm.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.NelderMead
member.summary: Contains the Nelder-Mead downhill simplex algorithm, which finds a minima when no gradient is available.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: A simplex is the convex hull of n+1 vertices. In 2D space, a simplex is a triangle, and in 3D space, a simplex is a tetragedron. The Nelder-Mead algoirthm starts with a set of n+1 points that are the vertices of a working simplex, S, and the corresponding set of function values. Through a sequence of transformations of the working simplex S, the function values at the vertices are decreased. At each step, the transformation is determined by computing one or more test points, and their function values, and by comparison of these function values with those vertices. The process is terminated with the S becomes sufficiently small or the function values are close enough.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.Fourier
member.summary: Contains Fourier transform methods.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: This class contains shared functions for Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), an algorithm that computes the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) which is obtained by decomposing a sequence of values into components of different frequencies. The DFT converts a finite sequence of equally-spaced samples of the discrete-time Fourier transform (DTFT), a complex valued function of frequency. A FFT rapidly computes these transformations by factorizing the DFT matrix into a product of mostly zero factors.

item.description: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.Fourier.FFT(System.Double[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs the fast Fourier transform (FFT) on a complex data array.
member.param: Data is a complex array of length n stored as a real array of length 2*n. n must be an integer power of 2.
Determines whether to perform an inverse transform.
member.remarks: Replaces the data array by its discrete Fourier transform. If inverse is true, then this routine replaces the data array by n times its inverse discrete Fourier Transform.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.Fourier.RealFFT(System.Double[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the Fourier transform of a set of n real-valued data points.
member.param: Data is a real array of length n. n must be an integer power of 2.
Determines whether to perform an inverse transform.
member.remarks: Replaces these data by the positive frequency half of their complex Fourier transform. The real-valued first and last components of the complex transform are returned as elements data(0) and data(1), respectively. This routine also calculates the inverse transform of a complex data array if it is the transform of real data. (Result in this case must be multiplied by 2/n.)

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.Fourier.Correlation(System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Computes the correlation of two real datasets. This is NOT a normalized correlation coefficient.
member.param: Data 1 is a real array of length n. n must be an integer power of 2.
Data 2 is a real array of length n. n must be an integer power of 2.
member.remarks: The answer is returned in wraparound order, i.e., correlations at increasing negative lags are in [n-1] on down to [n/2], while correlations at increasingly positive lags are in [0] up to [n/2-1].
member.returns: An array of the correlation between the two datasets

The maximum lag. The first lag begins at zero.
member.returns: A 2-column array with the first column contains the lags, and the second the autocorrelation.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.CholeskyDecomposition
member.summary: A class for solving a set of linear equations using Cholesky Decomposition.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para: The Cholesky decomposition or Cholesky factorization is a decomposition of a Hermitian, positive-definite matrix into the product of a lower triangular matrix and its conjugate transpose. The basic idea of this method includes decomposing a square positive-definite matrix by symmetrically applying column-clearing operations from Gaussian Elimination. This method is very useful for Monte Carlo simulations that is utilized in TotalRisk. This method is also roughly twice as efficient as the LU decomposition for solving systems of linear equations.

list.item: "Numerical Recipes: The art of Scientific Computing, Third Edition." Press et al. 2017.
"Numerical Methods for Engineers, Second Edition.", D.V. Griffiths and I.M. Smith, Taylor and Francis Group, 2006.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.SingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: A class for solving a set of linear equations using Singular Value Decomposition.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para:
Singular value decomposition (SVD) is one of the most useful matrix decomposition methods. Used in:
Reducing dimension of large data sets (PCA)
Separating "signal" from "noise" in real-world data
Identifying line / low-dim plane of best-fit to high dimensional data
Solving/interpreting linear systems of equations

list.item: "Numerical Recipes: The art of Scientific Computing, Third Edition. Press et al. 2017.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.Brent
member.summary: The Brent root-finding algorithm.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para:
Description:
This class contains a shared function for finding the solution to the equation f(x)=0 using Brent's method. Brent's method is a hybrid root-finding method that combines the use of bracketing methods, namely, the bisection method, secant method, and inverse quadratic interpolation.

list.item: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.Brent.Solve(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Use the Brent method to find a solution of the equation where f(x)=0.
member.param: The lower bound (a) of the interval containing the root.
The upper bound (b) of the interval containing the root.

Optional. Desired tolerance for both the root and the function value at the root. The root will be refined until the tolerance is achieved or the maximum number of iterations is reached. Default = 1e-8.
Optional. Maximum number of iterations. Default = 1000.

Optional. If set to true, an exception will be thrown if the routine fails to converge. If set to false, the root from the last iteration will be returned if the routine fails to converge. Default = True.
member.returns: The root to the equation f(x)=0 given the specified tolerance.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.Brent.Bracket(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Bracket the root by expanding outward.
member.param: The lower bound (a) of the interval containing the root.
The upper bound (b) of the interval containing the root.
Output. The function value at the lower bound.
Output. The function value at the upper bound.
Optional. Maximum number of iterations. Default = 1000.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.Secant
member.summary: The secant root-finding algorithm.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para:
Description:
This class contains a shared function for finding the solution to the equation, where f(x)=0 using the Secant method. The secant method is a root-finding procedure in numerical analysis that uses a series of roots of secant lines to better approximate a root of a function.

list.item: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.

Optional. Maximum number of iterations. Default = 1000.

Optional. If set to true, an exception will be thrown if the routine fails to converge. If set to false, the root from the last iteration will be returned if the routine fails to converge. Default = True.
member.returns: The root to the equation f(x)=0 given the specified tolerance.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.Bisection
member.summary: Contains the bisection root-finding algorithm.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para:
Description:
This class contains a shared function for finding the solution to the equation f(x)=0 using the bisection method. Bisection method is a variation of the incremental search method in which the interval is always divided in half. If a function changes sign over an interval, the function value at the midpoint is evaluated. The location of the root is then determined as lying within the interval for the next iteration.

list.item: "Numerical Recipes: The art of Scientific Computing, Third Edition." Press et al. 2017.
"Applied Numerical Methods with MATLAB for Engineers and Scientists, Third Edition.", Steven C. Chapra, McGraw-Hill, 2012.

member.summary: Use the bisection method to find the solution of the equation where f(x)=0.
member.param: This is the first guess at the root.
The lower bound of the interval containing the root.
The upper bound of the interval containing the root.

Optional. Desired tolerance for both the root and the function value at the root. The root will be refined until the tolerance is achieved or the maximum number of iterations is reached. Default = 1e-8.
Optional. Maximum number of iterations. Default = 1000.

Optional. If set to true, an exception will be thrown if the routine fails to converge. If set to false, the root from the last iteration will be returned if the routine fails to converge. Default = True.
member.returns: The root to the equation f(x)=0 given the specified tolerance.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.NewtonRaphson
member.summary: This class contains a shared function for finding the solution to the equation f(x)=0 using the Newton-Raphson method.

list.item: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Tiki Gonzalez, USACE Risk Management Center, julian.t.gonzalez@usace.army.mil

remarks.para:
Description:
In numerical analysis, Newton's method (also known as the NewtonRaphson method), named after Isaac Newton and Joseph Raphson, is a method for finding successively better approximations to the roots (or zeros) of a real-valued function. In this method, one takes an initial guess at the root, then a tangent can be extended from the point evaluated at the inital value. The point where this tangent crosses the x axis, usually represents an improved estimate of the root.

list.item: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991.
"Applied Numerical Methods with MATLAB for Engineers and Scientists, Third Edition.", Steven C. Chapra, McGraw-Hill, 2012.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.NewtonRaphson.Solve(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Use the basic Newton-Raphson method to find a solution of the equation f(x)=0.
member.remarks:
Remarks:
The basic algorithm aborts immediately if the root leaves the bound interval.
member.param: The function to find roots from.
The first derivative of the function to find roots from.
This is the first guess at the root (c).

Optional. Desired tolerance for both the root and the function value at the root. The root will be refined until the tolerance is achieved or the maximum number of iterations is reached. Default = 1e-8.
Optional. Maximum number of iterations. Default = 1000.

Optional. If set to true, an exception will be thrown if the routine fails to converge. If set to false, the root from the last iteration will be returned if the routine fails to converge. Default = True.
member.returns: The root to the equation f(x)=0 given the specified tolerance.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.RootFinding.NewtonRaphson.RobustSolve(System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Func{System.Double,System.Double},System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Use the robust Newton-Raphson method to find a solution of the equation f(x)=0.
member.remarks: Robust Newton-Raphson method falls back to bisection when over or undershooting the bounds.
member.param: The function to find roots from.
The first derivative of the function to find roots from.
This is the first guess at the root.
The lower bound of the interval containing the root. Aborts if it leaves the interval.
The upper bound of the interval containing the root. Aborts if it leaves the interval.

Optional. Desired tolerance for both the root and the function value at the root. The root will be refined until the tolerance is achieved or the maximum number of iterations is reached. Default = 1e-8.
Optional. Maximum number of iterations. Default = 1000.

Optional. If set to true, an exception will be thrown if the routine fails to converge. If set to false, the root from the last iteration will be returned if the routine fails to converge. Default = True.
member.returns: The root to the equation f(x)=0 given the specified tolerance.

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Beta
member.summary: A class for Beta functions.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description: The beta function is also know as Euler's integral. Denoted with the Greek capital beta, it has the following equation:
1 B(a,b) = t^(a-1)*(t-1)^(b-1) dt 0
It can also be written in terms of the Gamma function as:
B(a,b) = (a)*(b) / (a+b)

item.description: "Numerical Recipes, Routines and Examples in Basic", J.C. Sprott, Cambridge University Press, 1991. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta_function

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Evaluate
member.summary: Evaluation functions useful for computing polynomials.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Evaluate.Polynomial(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates a double precision polynomial.
member.remarks:
For sanity's sake, the value of N indicates the NUMBER of coefficients, or more precisely, the ORDER of the polynomial, rather than the DEGREE Of the polynomial. The two quantities differ by 1, but cause a great deal of confusion.
For example, a polynomial of order 4 in this function would be: coefficients[3]*x^3 + coefficients[2]*x^2 + coefficients[1]*x + coefficients[0]
References:
Based on a function contained in algorithm AS241, Applied Statistics, 1988, Vol. 37, No. 3.
member.param: The coefficients of the polynomial. Item[0] is the constant term.
The point at which the polynomial is to be evaluated.
member.returns: The polynomial with the given coefficients evaluated at x

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Evaluate.PolynomialRev(System.Double[],System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates a double precision polynomial. Coefficients are in reverse order.
member.remarks: For example, a polynomial of order 4 in this function would be: coefficients[0]*x^3 + coefficients[1]*x^2 + coefficients[2]*x + coefficients[3]
member.param: The coefficients of the polynomial. The last element in the list is the constant term.
The point at which the polynomial is to be evaluated.
Optional parameter to redefine the order of the polynomial to be n+1
member.returns: The polynomial with the given coefficients in reverse order evaluated at x

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Evaluate.PolynomialRev_1(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates a double precision polynomial. Coefficients are in reverse order, and coefficient(N) = 1.0.
member.remarks: For example, a polynomial of order 4 in this function would be: x^3 + coefficients[0]*x^2 + coefficients[1]*x + coefficients[2]

The point at which the polynomial is to be evaluated
member.returns: The polynomial with the given coefficients in reverse order, with 1 as the coefficient for the first term, evaluated at x

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Factorial
member.summary: Factorial functions.
member.remarks:
Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
Description: A factorial is a non negative integer n, denoted by n!, that is the product of all positive integers less than or equal to n. For example, 5! equals (1 * 2 * 3 * 4 * 5) which is 120. It is also important to note that 0! equals 1.
References:

n chose k = n! / k!(n-k)!

member.name: T:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Gamma
member.summary: Gamma (x) functions.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Description In mathematics, the gamma function (represented by the capital Greek letter ) is an extension of the factorial function, with its argument shifted down by 1, to real and complex numbers. That is, if n is a positive integer:
The gamma function is defined for all complex numbers except the negative integers and zero. For complex numbers with a positive real part, it is defined via an improper integral that converges:

This integral function is extended by analytic continuation to all complex numbers except the non-positive integers (where the function has simple poles), yielding the meromorphic function we call the gamma function. The gamma function is a component in various probability-distribution functions, and as such it is applicable in the fields of probability and statistics, as well as combinatorics.

References: This code was copied and modified from two primary sources: 1) THe LMOMENTS FORTAN package from J. R. M. Hosking; and 2) the Accord Math Library.
LMOMENTS package. Available at:
Accord Math Library,
Wikipedia contributors, "Gamma function,". Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Available at:
Cephes Math Library,

member.summary: The Stirling approximation
member.remarks:
In mathematics, Stirling's approximation (or Stirling's formula) is an approximation for factorials. It is a good approximation, leading to accurate results even for small values of n.

member.name: M:Numerics.Mathematics.SpecialFunctions.Gamma.Lanczos(System.Double)
member.summary: The Lancoz approximation
member.remarks:
In mathematics, the Lanczos approximation is a method for computing the gamma function numerically, published by Cornelius Lanczos in 1964. It is a practical alternative to the more popular Stirling's approximation for calculating the gamma function with fixed precision.
References:
member.returns: The Lancoz approximation of the Gamma function evaluated at the given x

member.name: T:Numerics.Sampling.LatinHypercube
member.summary: A class to perform Latin hypercube sampling (LHS).

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

Stratified sampling is used to generate uniform random numbers by dividing the interval [0,1) into n bins of equal probability, where n is the total number of samples required.
In each iteration:
A random number is generated to select one of the remaining bins.
A second random number is generated to select a value within the chosen bin.
The selected bin is marked as used and will not be selected in subsequent iterations.
This process is repeated until all n bins have been sampled, ensuring that each bin is selected exactly once.

member.name: T:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.HMC
member.summary: This class performs Bayesian MCMC using the Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) method.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil
The optimal acceptance rate for this sampler is 65%, whereas Metropolis-Hastings samplers have an optimal rate of 23.4%.

member.summary: The function for evaluating the gradient of the log-likelihood function.

member.returns: Returns the gradient of the log-likelihood function.

member.name: M:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.HMC.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.List{Numerics.Distributions.IUnivariateDistribution},Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.LogLikelihood,Numerics.Mathematics.LinearAlgebra.Vector,System.Double,System.Int32,Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.HMC.Gradient)
member.summary: Constructs a new HMC sampler.
member.param: Optional. The mass vector for the momentum distribution. Default = Identity.
Optional. The leapfrog step size. Default = 0.1.
Optional. The number of leapfrog steps. Default = 50.
Optional. The function for evaluating the gradient of the log-likelihood. Numerical finite difference will be used by default.

member.name: P:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.HMC.Mass
member.summary: The mass vector for the momentum distribution.

member.name: P:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.HMC.StepSize
member.summary: The leapfrog step size. Default = 0.1.
member.remarks: This controls the size of each leapfrog step in the simulation. A smaller step size can lead to more accurate simulations of the Hamiltonian dynamics but requires more steps to cover the same distance, increasing computational cost. A larger step size reduces computational cost but can lead to inaccurate simulations and a higher rejection rate. The step size is often tuned during the warm-up phase of the HMC algorithm to achieve an optimal balance.

member.name: P:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.HMC.Steps
member.summary: The number of leapfrog steps. Default = 50.
member.remarks: This refers to the number of leapfrog steps taken in each HMC iteration. The total distance covered in the parameter space during each iteration is the product of the step size and the number of steps. The number of steps determines how far the algorithm moves in parameter space before proposing a new sample. A larger number of steps allows the algorithm to explore more of the parameter space but can increase computational time. Like the step size, the number of steps can also be tuned, though it is often set to a fixed value.

member.name: T:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.MCMCDiagnostics
member.summary: A class for assessing Bayesian MCMC convergence diagnostics.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

member.name: M:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.MCMCDiagnostics.EffectiveSampleSize(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double})
member.summary: Compute the effective sample size.
member.param: The series of posterior samples to evaluate.

member.name: M:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.MCMCDiagnostics.GelmanRubin(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.List{Numerics.Mathematics.Optimization.ParameterSet}},System.Int32)
member.summary: The Gelman-Rubin diagnostic.

remarks.para: The Gelman-Rubin diagnostic tests for lack of convergence by comparing the variance between multiple chains to the variance within each chain. If convergence has been achieved, the between-chain and within-chain variances should be identical. To be most effective in detecting evidence for non convergence, each chain should have been initialized to starting values that are dispersed relative to the target distribution.

member.param: The list of Markov Chains to be evaluated. The chains must be of equal length.
The number of warm up MCMC iterations to discard at the beginning of the chains.

member.name: M:Numerics.Sampling.MCMC.MCMCDiagnostics.MinimumSampleSize(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the minimum sample size rounded to the nearest 100 based on the Raftery-Lewis method.
member.param: The posterior quantile of interest; e.g., 0.975.
The acceptable tolerance for this quantile; e.g., 0.005.
Probability of being within the range of tolerance; e.g., 0.95.
member.returns: The minimum sample size as an integer, rounded to the nearest thousands place.

member.name: T:Numerics.Sampling.SobolSequence
member.summary: A class for generating a Sobol sequence.

remarks.para: Authors: Haden Smith, USACE Risk Management Center, cole.h.smith@usace.army.mil

A Sobol sequence is a low-discrepancy sequence with the property that for all values of N, its subsequence (x1, ... xN) has a low discrepancy. It can be used to generate pseudo-random points in a space S, which are equi-distributed.

list.item: The implementation already comes with support for up to 21201 dimensions with direction numbers calculated from
This code was converted from the Apache Math Commons.
"Numerical Recipes: The art of Scientific Computing, Third Edition. Press et al. 2017.
